pros: It's one of the few conservative institutions/businesses that exist out there so you don't have to feel afraid to share conservative or Christian opinions. Paid time off is generous and benefits are decent, but the pay is low. I've worked for 2 different departments and some are awful and some are pretty good just depending on where you are. Pretty forgiving with employees from what I've seen (people that should've been fired for being bad at their jobs are often given second chances). The biggest pro is the free education for employees and their spouses/kids, but I'd say working here isn't worth it if you're not using this benefit.
cons: Pay is awful. I make 41k a year in a job where the standard is around 50k, and this isn't just my current position/department. Pretty much every department is underpaid by a lot so people just end up using working here as a stepping stone to finding better-paying jobs. This isn't a case of a struggling university either as almost every year has record enrollment levels (and record revenue/profits). The money just seems to be spent on crazy building projects, the student experience, and the executives/high-profile sports coaches. There is also an annual Cost of Living paycheck (which in the past was called a bonus) which is very deceptive as it is given out right around Christmas time which gives it the appearance of being a Christmas bonus when in reality it's a standard Cost of Living raise that every company gives out every year, but instead of spreading the money out through each paycheck throughout the year, you get it all at once to make it appear that you got a Christmas bonus when in reality you didn't. They did give out a $1000 Christmas bonus in 2021 in addition to the CoL paycheck, but they didn't continue this again in 2022. Pay raises are also handled ridiculously in my department. In the vast majority of companies, a pay raise is calculated based on how well you perform and yet every single raise I've gotten in the 7 years of working here has been a flat $1,000. I've always gotten above-average perfomance reviews, but why even try harder to be a good employee if you're going to get the same flat raise as those who are putting in less effort, worse quality work, or who have a worse attitude? You also have to deal with being somewhat associated with the latest Liberty drama as well which isn't a huge deal to me personally, but I'm sure liberal employees hate it.

You will be thrown into a sea of hundreds of thousands of online students who count on you to be able to solve all of their problems when you yourself are just a mere student at the university. No one specializes in certain subject matter of degrees every advisor is forced to “learn” all of it which leads to so much error because it is just too much information to be able to understand all of it.

Not only are you busy constantly but the department will voluntarily create more chaos for themselves but scheduling what they call voice blasts generally telling students to sign up for classes.

They also will not allow you to advance in the company if there is a better opportunity for you or you would be happier somewhere else. When applying and interviewing for different positions at the company there is a form that has to be filled out by leadership in order to get permission to do so. Due to them being so short staffed they have actually denied people of these signed forms and individuals have missed out on better opportunities due to it. 

They do not care about your mental health and will hold things you struggle with against you. They don’t care if your marriage is on the rocks or a family member passed away, if you’re not at 100% you’re most likely getting written up or fired. 

Before everything with Jerry Jr went down I attended this school for my bachelors excited to be able to be in an environment that I thought shared the same wants and inspiration to glorify the Lord. I took a job there in order to utilize the education benefit to pursue a masters and seeing how the school was actually run ruined my relationship with God.

These people do not glorify god, they do not treat their employees as they would want to be treated. You are expendable, you will be worked like a horse, and when there is nothing left you are no longer of value to them. 

Despite all of this, at least there is free coffee and sometimes they buy doughnuts. Praise the all knowing “god” for that one.

DO NOT WORK HERE

pros: The people. We have students who berate us on the phone and then have a management team that doesn't back us up, but the people that work around you support and encourage you. The people, friends, I have made the past few years will be missed the most.
cons: Pretty much everything else. No ability for advancement. Even with positive reviews every year I have received, I have sat in the exact same spot. Expectations are horribly communicated. I could truly go on and on. I have been in the work force for many years and I've never had a worse experience with a job then Liberty. I have never even heard of a mangement team treating their employees as badly as Advising where if you run out of vacation/sick days at the end of the year and get sick, (even with a doctor's note) you can be put on corrective review or possibly fired (this is the absolute truth). If you have a family, don't apply for this position unless you don't like them, because with the horrible schedule you will get, you will never see them. Also, with a large family you won't be able to support them with the pay LU offers.

review_title: Only take this job if you are desperate
job_title: Liberty University Online Admissions Counselor in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Occasionally they will let you go home early if it is slow
cons: everything else, the most exhausting, difficult job I have ever had

review_title: low pay and new VP is wreaking havoc!
pros: I am a graduate and loved my time as a student so working there seemed to be a wonderful opportunity.
cons: Once you reach your highest pay for that position, you cannot get an increase in pay.  The pay is not great to raise a family on and that moved us all from salary to hourly.  The new VP is causing upheaval and people are looking to get out of LUO as quickly as they can find a job.  He is going to run it in the ground and he'll do it on the backs of the employees who have been dedicated to their job.

pros:
The people you work with become fast friends. Seriously, some of the best people you'll ever work with.

Opportunities to work remote and go to conferences. Good salaries for the area. The work you do can immediately impact thousands of students. Access to a top notch gym. Lots of great food options on campus.
cons:
Unfortunately the day to day can be soul crushing. You have very little ownership of the work you do. Even if you were hired based on your expertise and have years of experience in a particular area, you will be passed over by someone that has befriended a manager/director. 

There's a very pessimistic attitude among coworkers about any sort of positive change as in the past those changes have failed. When changes do occur, they happen quickly and without proper planning. The repercussions end up causing even more work to pile up.

pros: Made the most I have made at a job so far. I was able to finish my Bachelor's degree without going into further debt.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of staff, management, and directors. There was barely any communication as to why the expectations were the way that they were except that they "help the students". We read from a script and helped to answer student's questions, but the confusing bureaucracy made it difficult to excel at being "helpful" consistently. Managers were instructed to be overly critical of staff members in order to drive fear and ownership, even though there was very little that was in the staff member's control. In addition, opportunities to be promoted were mainly based off of personality and not work expertise, meaning a staff member could get promoted because they were friends with management, even if there was a more qualified candidate and it would be justified by the directors.

pros: I have worked here since 2012. Pay is okay for this town, but not in line with other universities for same job: about 25% less actually. With little employment competition in Lynchburg their is little need to increase wages.  Benefits are excellent especially the free tuition for employees and their immediate family.
cons: Management leadership is lacking skills and legacy employees from the old guard need to move on or get proper leadership and management training for the skills and talents needed in this current age.  HR is severely lacking and needs management training.  Annual raises are non-existent for most workers.  Performance reviews never happen for most. If your manager is not up to the task do not expect him/her to get any assistance from HR to improve his/her management skills.

review_title: It's a good place to start, then leave
job_title: Business Data Analyst in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Because of the pay scale difference, even in comparison to other higher ed institutions in the area, Liberty can't really hire people with experience.  They don't come to LU unless they want their kids to go to school for free, they are personally involved in the school/Thomas Road, or can't escape Lynchburg.  This makes it easy to find entry level jobs that will train you in a desired field.  You can get 4-5 years of experience with industry standard software and applications, then move on.
cons:
-Because of the high overturn in IT/IS, good people are constantly being replaced by inexperienced staff.
-Upper management are untrustworthy 
-Upper management do not care about staff
-The pay is awful
-You have to pay for parking

review_title: Ignore Jerry, Get Your Degree, and Move On
pros:
- If you are a new graduate looking for a job to build your resume, it’s a fine place to work.

- Same if you want to use the benefits for a free degree.

- The people you work with are great people with big hearts. It’s a great work environment because of this.
cons:
- LU isn’t a place to build a long range career, it’s a stepping stone to your future. 

- Your job is never safe. I’ve seen many good, hardworking people who have been kicked to the curb for no reason after faithfully serving here for 10/15/20 years... staff and faculty.

- Below average pay unless you are in the upper 2% of the organization. They have thousands of graduates that would gladly work for your sub-average pay, and they don’t mind seeing you go if it means not paying you what you are worth.

- President cares more about his political career than the University

pros: Liberty provided me a lot of experience in my professional career field. I started entry level and learned a lot, while also building great relationships with my coworkers. My coworkers were fabulous people.
cons: Having worked specifically for the athletics department, individuals are greatly overworked. 60-80 hour weeks are the ordinary. Compensation is also poor for the amount of time required to perform the job responsibilities, which are many. Little care seemed to be given for the amount of time put in to the job. Money was plentiful, but not for salaries and compensation. I never received a performance review while there, and my only 'promotion' was given when they decided they did not want me to be hourly anymore (due to overtime) and switched me over to salary without first informing me. It was highly unprofessional and a leading cause as to why I left the organization.

review_title: good place to work while in school
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Most people that I interacted with were very nice people. And having the opportunity to teach at such a young age was pretty amazing.
cons:
The pay is herendously low. They attempt to compensate by offering to allow you to go to school for free. However, that obviously runs out when you're done with school. 
Also, they're a pretty terrible with helping you to find job placement after you graduate. But that's really the school in general. 
Also, the GSA program is pretty unorganized so a lot do the time you have to wing it and make things up as you go. 
Also the fact that the pay is so low is made even worse by the fact that you do the work of a full professor and you're not paid for it. They basically just designed the program in such a way that they wouldn't have to hire more professors and pay them more. Instead they just hire a bunch of GSAs and have them do all the work and pay them penny's. It's pretty terribel. And probably illegal honestly.

review_title: Good Benefits, Poor Pay, Patriarchal Corporate Culture
pros: You won't find a better group of peers (not superiors) to work with. The benefits are excellent with health, dental, vision and life insurance as well as the matching 401k. The day-to-day operations are run by people in their mid 20's which is both good and bad. The good is that it is easy for a younger individual to get some excellent work experience.
cons: The pay is not competitive with the private section, seeing at the University is non-profit. That being said, the school has more than enough money, it just isn't spread around. Management is incredibly patriarchal and it is tough to climb the ladder out of middle management without being one of the good 'ol boys. This leadership also makes it very difficult to improve the corporate culture, which tends to have very low morale.

job_title: Online Academic Advisor in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Loved the young energy. Fast paced work atmosphere. Runs like a well-oiled machine considering the size of the university. Christian atmosphere. Prayed before every work day with your shift's management team. They pay for up to 18 hours of classes a year once you have been there 6 months.
cons: Very low pay for a pretty tough job. TONS of information to learn and be held responsible for and not much pay to recognize you for the amount of work you do. The residential school is funded by the online school so you are making the school a lot more money than you will ever see on your end. Every minute of your day is literally monitored by Cisco software (including how long you spend in the bathroom).

review_title: Three years of my life wasted.
pros: They have great benefits, which is the only reason I haven't turned in my notice sooner.
cons: Everything about this place is crud. The management is horrible - there is no communication, ever. HR is even worse. When a complaint is made, they don't do anything about it and the worker is to blame. It seems like no one is on the same page and every department picks and chooses what they want to enforce in "employee handbook"  All they care about is making money off of students to build the campus bigger. There aren't any Christian values and honestly, I'm surprised I lasted as long as I did. After three years, I'm going to put my two weeks in tomorrow because I honestly cannot continue to be in such a hostile environment. I don't really have a plan but I would rather live in the uncertainty of where I'm going next, then spend any more time working for this place.

pros:
- Various departments within the university are great. If you find one of those good ones, you'll enjoy your job, provided you can accept the overall culture of micro-management and reactive thinking.
- Enjoyed working with folks in my department, and have built some life-long friendships
- Challenging job, you will be stretched (a good thing)
- Christian environment
- Tuition benefit
cons:
- Too may 'yes' men, executive mandates lead to a highly reactive and stressful environment.
- Too many young managers. Extremely sharp people, but very little real world experience.

pros: Wonderful coworkers, excellent students, great atmosphere, low-cost area, new facilities
cons: Huge bureaucracy, loads of red tape, major emphasis on athletics and marketing over academics, organizational politics (partly academia, partly overly polite and indirect Southern culture -- can't rock the boat), obnoxiously political leadership

job_title: Resident Admissions Counselor in Lynchburg, VA
pros:
-Benefits and (limited) paid time off
-Nice campus
-Good coworkers
-Pays the bills
cons: This is the perfect place to work if you don’t mind being overworked and micromanaged. Management focuses solely on numbers, rather than implementing strategies that work, the best interest of the students, or employees’ wellbeing. The methods used to try to hit certain numbers were outdated and didn’t work, and then the employees were to blame. The job itself was extremely monotonous and stressful, and break time was very limited. There was also a lot of favoritism in the office, and the people who worked the hardest were not recognized. Reward systems changed frequently, taking away any type of motivation; management often relied on threats to get desired behavior from employees. Long hours with little to show for it other than a paycheck and increased stress.

review_title: Certainly not perfect, but a pretty good place to work overall
pros: Good atmosphere of professionals pulling toward a common, over-arching goal. Christian values are not just spoken, but actively lived here. Some of the brightest and most energetic younger managers are committed to providing the best possible product for our students.
cons:
Internal politics is still present (alas!), so sometimes one has to be careful where one "steps" so as not to irritate the wrong people. (This is common with 98% of organizations on the planet.)
Sometimes, internal communications are not thought through, so they create more questions than they answer.

review_title: Stay away from Financial Aid positions!
pros:
Ability to dress professionally. 
Health and Medical benefits are reasonable.
Office setting keeps you from working outside or inside warehouse.
cons:
Too many immature, 20 somethings who are in leadership positions.
Expectation is that you remain quiet and not speak to the Coordinator (Trainer).
Office managers stand behind Coordinators even when they are blatantly wrong.
Micromanagement at its worst.
Atmosphere based on corrective action for anyone who dares to speak up about anything that is a reflection on leadership.
No one hardly speaks to one another. Fake smiles and fake chit chat about your educational background is about the most you will get.

review_title: Liberty is exciting, but anxiety and fear can overcome you fast.
pros: Being on a school schedule is nice. Lynchburg is a good town. Liberty is an exciting place to be.
cons: Highly political. High in fear-based leadership. Employees, no matter what department, feel expendable. Communication between the higher-ups and the rest of the staff and faculty community is very poor. Employees often don't know what's going on, but must submit to whatever changes happen - which happens often. Accountability for leaders is very low, and also qualifications. Many Vice Presidents have no prior experience and the newest VP for Spiritual Development doesn't even have a college degree.

review_title: Not the Worst. Not the Best.
pros: Good benefits with health/dental/vision insurance and 401k matching up to 5%. Good paid vacation.
cons:
They have a "You Matter" marketing campaign where money is given to departments to make employees feel valuable. But, in today's world, money equals employee value. If you value your employees, give them raises and put them at market value. 
So many people leave here because of not enough pay. You are constantly learning to work with new people which can be a good or bad thing depending on the type of person hired.

job_title: IT Operations Engineer in Lynchburg, VA
pros:
There are some really wholesome and talented people at LU. 
Remote work is becoming more acceptable. 
Pay can be very competitive for the area after a fashion. 
CIO is working on helping rightsize compensation.
Training opportunities are very good, and free continuing education is great as long as you can balance online education with work. 
Plenty of potential to  learn, implement, and support new technologies once you build clout.
Larger companies have been known to recruit directly from LU - such as Red Hat, Amazon, and Oracle.
cons:
Parking can be horrible during the school year.
Morale gets pretty low at times. 
Often have to leave, threaten to leave, or find your niche during a mass exodus in order to achieve proper compensation.
Too much nepotism.
HR.

pros: Amazing job! loved every minute of it! actually its seriously hard but it is extremely rewarding, but it is absolutely not for the faint of heart! you need to be pretty excellent to become an RA but they do a good job selecting candidates.
cons: Room checks, Football halls are tough, room checks, convo, incident reports. its actually a love hate relationship with all of those things. God turns them into awesome opprotunities all the time but its tough to stay faithful to completening those duties some times.

pros: There are some genuinely good people in the organization, it is a fairly easy foot in the door to gain experience, and the education benefit is helfpful.
cons: The pay is very low, management is poor and uninformed for a large part, and the overall care for people is rather low. Furthermore, the organization runs on a top down, brother-in-law system; meaning its all about knowing (and sucking up) to the right people, and from an internal control standpoint, if people don't like a decision, they skip any command chain to take the issue to top management.

review_title: Great starting point for career but not much else
pros: Liberty is a great place to start your career, but that’s about it.
cons: You won’t be able to advance your career experience or salary much at all. Working here is not a stepping stone nor does it prepare you for corporate America. Often times felt like I worked in a summer church camp. Very strict hours, not flexible with working remote, micromanaging managers, low pay, and the constant fear of jugment if you don’t think the same way and believe in the same things as those around you. I felt like I always had to live a lie, and I consider myself to be a moderate, and “progressive conservative” with Christian beliefs.

review_title: Great department managers; high pressure environment with numbers (not people) minded upper management
pros:
Excellent co-workers and department managers
Steady hours
Overall friendly environment
cons:
Minimal pay for entry level positions
Very high pressure, call center environment
Upper management seems much more concerned with numbers than with people - quantity over quality
Angry students who are inevitably casualties due to the fast paced environment and frequent change in personnel and policies

job_title: Law School Coordinator of Recruitment in Lynchburg, VA
pros: It is certainly the largest Christian University in the world.  It has great benefits and amenities for both students, faculty, and staff alike.
cons: There is virtually no ability to advance in your position.  They do not treat (or pay) employees like they matter because everyone can be easily replaced by the hundreds willing to take their place.

review_title: Good place to start your career
pros: The strongest part of Liberty University is its people. Most everyone there is friendly and incredibly willing to help with just about anything. During my tenure at LU, I was given opportunities that I don't think I would have gotten elsewhere. Liberty is always trying to break new ground and be on the cutting edge (at least the arenas I worked in) and the skills I gained have helped me excel in other areas of my life. The health insurance is outstanding, education benefits are helpful, and some of the other perks (gym, misc. discounts) are a nice add-on. Most positions are incredibly stable, and with some effort you can move up quickly (depending on the department).
cons:
The most common complaint you'll hear at Liberty is the gap between what Liberty pays versus other employers. Because Liberty is a non-profit, the ranges are considerably lower than other organizations. The frustration comes from a seemingly endless building and campus improvement budget, but little to no salary improvement efforts. Liberty is able to pay a lower salary range because of the other benefits; despite a high turnover rate, there will almost always be someone willing to fill a position because of education or health benefits. Discussing your salary is a fireable offense. 

Human Resources is one of the most frustrating entities to work with. During my time at LU, it seemed as if HR was actively working against the employees. The constant secrecy and clandestine nature does nothing to improve this perception. 

Executive level employees seem to be in a different class, where the rules don't apply to them - leading to frustration of lower-level staff members. Executive level issues come across as petty, while some more serious issues affecting lower-level staff are ignored. For a long period of time, there was an incredible fear of administration. Stories and rumors of people being let go for speaking up about serious issues abound, and everyone knows someone that was let go for saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. This isn't as prevalent as it used to be, as administration has changed, but it is definitely an element.

Some of the staff work environments are not that exciting. Part of the campus is a former factory that was gifted to the university. While the portions that students will see have been remodeled, the sections a large part of staff work in need to be renovated. I can think of a bathroom that hasn't been remodeled to any extent since the early 1980s. With a little investment, Liberty could easily improve the work environment to allow for more collaboration and creativity, but after more than a decade, this has yet to change.

review_title: Decent starter job; move on quickly
pros: If full time benefited, you will receive free tuition for one of each degree level (i.e. bachelors, masters, doctorate). However, you are limited on the number of classes you can take at a time, and you cannot earn a lower level degree than what you presently have.
cons: Low pay, poor advancement opportunities, very little training for most employees and a plethora of sacred cows.

pros: Coworkers are genuinely nice. Usually a stress-free environment.
cons: No performance reviews or opportunities for salary increases even though reviews were promised bi-annually. Wasted money on You Matter events. Wasted money on college infrastructure. Management refuses to fight for their employees' needs.  Lack of encouragement to seek out and obtain certifications. Lack of parking spots even though we're required to pay for our own parking spots.

pros: Terrific company that cares for their employees. Great education benefits. Office environment is very relaxed with a business casual style. Open cubicle system that gives a feel that you are not in the regular office setting but still have your own area to personalize. The warm environment makes the work day easily to manage.
cons: Vacation benefits are lacking for those who stay longer than 5 years. Even though they say no salary cap, positions do have them. Hard to express your concerns on ways to improve.

pros: Great option if you are looking to have your education paid for.
cons: Very little room for advancement, often political in nature.  Compensation is extremely low and is typically only justified by those that are taking advantage of the education benefits

review_title: Lots of work, no appreciation, and below market salary
pros: Great coworkers, hiring process is efficient
cons: Poor upper and middle management, slow HR department, inconsistent expectations, low salary, limited training, high turnover, little chance for advancement, awful insurance

review_title: A great place to feel like you are apart of a family.
pros: You will be apart of the most amazing caring environment that encourages you to succeed, but to also grow as an individual and professional as well. A family-oriented job which helps to ensure that you are well taken care of and loved.
cons: The hours for some of the positions are not conducive with families; sometimes having to work late 2nd shift or even working 10 hour shifts depending on the needs of the business sometimes place a damper on wanting to continue with the company long term.

review_title: good salary, hours, benefits. Micromanagement of every minute of your day.
pros: Great salary, benefits, nice offices and employee incentives. Office culture is good and there is time built in to get to know your team mates periodically. Free education after 6 months of employment is also a bonus.
cons: micromanagement and a feeling of disposability among the staff. Also a low level of transparency from upper management. Values that are given from the top down and put out in PR campaigns, don't always translate into how the staff are actually treated in the policies that are implemented

pros: I worked in the IT section of the school for over 5 years. The wages/salary are competitive with other Christian institutions.  The benefits package is about normal, but not excellent
cons: The Culture of the work place changed dramatically during the time I was employed. It started out as a work-family, but toward the end, it shifted into a business with a shark-eat-shark attitude.

pros:
The faculty was great and were above reproach in my area.
The students are wonderful.
The facility and resources are top notch.
cons: The administration of the school is on a total business model, which is fine for a business, but doesn't work well for a school.  The primary objective for a school should be to educate and you can't educate without failing those that don't demonstrate actual learning. The business model for retention supercedes the actual performance and learning of the student in some cases.

job_title: UG Admissions Counselor in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Decent salary compared to cost of living in the central VA area. Health and education benefits for employees and dependents adds value to salary. Paid vacation and flexible schedules. Management willing to work with employees for time off and extenuating circumstances. Employees offered "perks" such paid time off for work events.
cons: Not able to make more money due to salary caps. Hard to move up due to politics. Hard to move out to different department due to HR career advancement policies.

pros: Your coworkers are some genuinely good people. Being in a university setting, change is always happening. You grow and face project deadlines that will challenge you to be better. Through these challenges, you will gain valuable experience.
cons: The higher you move up the ladder, the more discouraged you become witnessing the behavior of senior leaders. Enrollment, Spiritual Development, and other divisions are all led by people that act one way on the job but will fire and step over anyone that gets in the way of their agenda. It is an open secret that departments share horror stories about each other's leaders.

pros: The people I worked with in the Graduate English Department was great: very committed to helping you succeed and always there to give advice. The hours as a GSA were excellent, and teaching was a great experience.
cons: The work-life balance was a little difficult: they wanted your pursuit of your Master's degree and being a GSA to be your whole life - which is unhealthy and unrealistic. Of course, graduate programs are difficult and do require a great deal of time and effort, but you need to have other pursuits outside of your education or you will be quite unhappy.

pros: Not to be a shill, but Liberty has some amazing benefits.  Not only is the education free, but the HDHP insurance option is crazy.  $3k deductable, aftewards 100% coverage.  That's better than VA Tech and other institutions.  With the 5% match for the 403(b) and (finally) competitive pay with very, very low pressure and never over 40 hours/week even in lower management, it's a great place to work.
cons: Not much... will encounter varying levels of management, but with the right attitude anything is possible here.

pros: Terrific coworkers who care about doing a great job.
cons: Severely underpaid employees unless you are on a Director level.  Leadership is poor and they don't know what they are doing .  The COO is making poor decisions and now the University is being run like a Money Grabbing Business instead of a University.  Parking is an absolute nightmare because they allow students to park at the main administration building also.  Oh yeah - and they charge staff to park, as if the low pay wasn't bad enough they make you pay to park at your office building.

pros:
Supervisors/middle management in IT seem to care about their employees and encourage a friendly work environment. My current immediate supervisors are some of the best I've had at any workplace.

Tuition benefits are good and are the main reason about 70% of employees continue to work here.

Retirement matching up to 5% of yearly salary seems to be higher than average.
cons:
With a handful of exceptions, upper management seems to forget that they have actual people working for them. 

Wages are significantly (about 25% or more from my personal experience) lower than industry averages in the area.

Upper management does not recognize workers that take on odd or unusual tasks and only considers metrics when handing out promotions. Many times these metrics are inaccurate or are too general to accurately reflect individual performance.

Jerry Falwell Jr. is far more interested in using his position to gain the ear of political pundits than running a university that benefits the lives of the students that attend the university. Additionally, the online course offerings are abysmal and in many cases I have been able to find materials online for free that offer better information than a $3000+ course.

You have to pay the university for the privilege of going to work by having the cost of a parking pass deducted from your pay. Even after that there is no employee-only parking, so there are many, many instances where you cannot find a parking spot without having to walk or take a shuttle to your office.

Turnover is incredibly high, since the pay is not competitive in the least. If you're not taking classes then why on earth are you working here!?

To follow up with the last point, the University abuses it's status as a Christian university to exploit workers into accepting unfair pay under the guise of working for a higher purpose.

review_title: Could Be An Amazing Employer....But Isn't
job_title: Contact Center Agent in Lynchburg, VA
pros:
• Education benefits are decent.

• 5% match on retirement contributions is above average (must remain for 5 years to be fully vested though which doesn't happen for most employees).

• One of the few places in life you feel confident you won't be harassed for expressing conservative views.
cons:
• Pay is very low (one unexpected bill makes things difficult  for me during a month and I'm quite 
frugal with my money). Should probably be about 20% higher. 

• Management micromanages you.

• The raises are pathetic (I was given a flat 1K raise instead of a calculated percentage based on my above average performance on my yearly review).

• You have to pay for a parking pass (some $100 odd dollars depending on where you work) which is absolutely ridiculous. Even after that you don't get employee specific parking.

• Turnover is on par with a minimum wage job, and you end up having to pull more weight than the newer, lesser experienced employees around you. 

• Many employees likely feel complacent when receiving a lower wage due to the fact that it is a Christian University which is not acceptable on any level.

review_title: Terrible pay with no care from administration
pros:
Free tuition
Good co-workers
Health benefits are satisfactory
cons: Poverty-level pay, very stressful work, pressure from administration, constant new job duties added, overtime work with no pay, never includes raises, HR refuses to respond to emails

pros: This is an amazingly supportive, caring place to work. They have a "You Matter" campaign with posters in all employee areas reminding employees that no matter their position, they are all important to the university. The department leadership teams are required to lead meetings with prayer and Scripture readings. You are privvy to hear world renowned guest speakers once a week during the academic semesters. The buildings are always clean. There are multiple cafeterias, an on-campus post office, and an on-site doctor's office. Best of all, full time employees (and their spouses) can take up to 18 credit hours per year for FREE through LU Online.
cons:
-The pay for most staff positions is well below industry standards and is not competitive with other universities. I earned my Bachelor's Degree from LU in 2011 and took a job as a department secretary in 2013 so I could go to grad school or free. One of the mandatory requirements for my job was having a bachelor's degree, but even then, I was hired at $8.68/hour. I should have been paid anywhere from $16-$20 for that job, and would have been paid that elsewhere. At first, I wasn't worried about it. I figured that with the free tution benefit, it was probably a wash. Unfortunately, my bank account didn't agree... I had to leave after only 3 months. But my department threw a huge going away party for me with catered food and gave me a $100 gift card. (Seriously, the BEST co-workers EVER!)

-Parking is ridiculous! Too many people (students, faculty, staff, visitors) and not nearly enough parking, plus you have to pay for annual parking passes. Last year, mine was over $400.

pros: Great department to work for. Energetic staff members and Liberty University is a growing Athletic Department so many jobs are opening up and a lot of positive growth
cons: Not many people move on from this University. They get a job and stick with it because they love the environment. So not many outsiders are allowed into this school.  Also the harsh rules that this school has on students, faculty, and staff  can sometimes is a bit harsh

pros: The Christian environment is nice. I enjoy teaching the courses. The students are great.
cons: Don't ever hope of teaching full time or having benefits. Just get it out of your mind. The online school is an army of adjuncts. You can never depend on having classes. The online school supports the residential school financially, but the university doesn't really care about the online students as much.  Adjuncts are the bottom of the barrel.

review_title: It's a very mixed bag, some parts are great, some are very bad.
pros: Some benefits, help foreign students/workers keep a work visa to stay in the country, stable environment.
cons: Way too many intra/inter-office politics, pay and benefits not always on par with market, employees generally treated as seats to be filled and not often enough promoted internally. Also, rules for employees are very restrictive.

pros:
It's fun and interesting

Really nice experiences with students
cons:

Focus in more on tedious metrics than educational quality

pros: Great benefits, they will pay for education 100%.  In addition, the medical benefits offered are also very good and depending on the office you work in the pay is not great but not terrible either.

review_title: A stepping stone to bigger and better things
pros: The people are all fantastic. Everyone is very talented and collaborative thinking between workers is great. It's interesting to dip your feet in a small "enterprise" environment. It's easy to make lasting connections, learn new things quickly, and gain experience for future opportunities.
cons:
Ideas never make it through more than 2 layers of management before being shot down — and key decisions are made 4 or 5 layers up from workers. Similarly, communication from upper management rarely makes its way down to workers. There are many "secrets" and rumors because the facts are never communicated clearly to staff. The result is that workers feel confused, disoriented, distrusted and more like "worker monkeys" than people.

It doesn't help that almost all positions have a "glass ceiling" — you can only get so far before the only way forward is management. The result is that workers are promoted to management based on experience and "time worked" rather than leadership abilities or organizational skills. It really explains the lack of good judgment in management.

Another problem is that there is no policy regarding pay, except that discussion of pay is strictly frowned upon. Performance reviews are entirely informal and off the books. The only managers who will actually talk to workers are the ones who have no power to actually decide things or give raises. The people who get raises are the ones who constantly bother managers until the proper paperwork is submitted. Management definitely isn't on your team when it comes to this. Personally I had at least 3 managers break promises to me regarding this.

review_title: Dependable, pleasant place to work, but the public appearance does not reflect their internal realities.

- If you have a family, you will need supplemental income from a second job or from a working spouse because the salary caps are quite low.

review_title: They say you matter...but it never felt like that
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Lynchburg, VA
pros: I did meet some great people while working for LUO, and it was nice being a part of a team where everyone was around the same stage of life as you. The benefits are nice, and I did gain some experience in various areas of communication that ended up helping in my career pursuit.
cons: Extreme micro management, and use a style of fear-based leadership to try and control people. I understand that since LUO is so large it's hard to oversee that many people, but I promise monitoring people so much and not trusting them is not the answer. People are not robots, and that's often times what it felt like. The pay is also nowhere near what you would see at another university. It's common knowledge that if you want people to stick around longer, treat them fairly and pay them more. They run people into the ground with these high stress positions, and then after maybe a year or two most people leave because of the stress, legalism, and lack of raises. You feel indispensable because you know since LUO is in a college town every year there will always be tons of graduates ready to take your position if there's something you don't like.

review_title: Good starting job. Not a place to stay long term.
pros: Employees are generally kind and caring. I made a lot of great, long term friends at Liberty. Benefits are pretty much unbeatable. Decent amount of room for progression in the company. A lot of great experience and training to build a great resume. Free* tuition for those that are interesting. Relaxed hours and ability to work from home when needed.
cons:
Micromanaging is a plague at Liberty. Management simply does NOT trust their employees. They want every second of work you do to be logged. Liberty is very metric heavy. Management wants metrics on things that are essentially meaningless to them. All of the time tracking and metrics gathering is a colossal waste of time that could be put to better use. Expect to spend an hour each day recounting what all work you have done. This includes phone calls, replying to emails, being stopped by coworkers, and of course the hour wasted logging time.

Nepotism run rampant. One stands a better chance at a raise or a promotion if you are good friends and/or related to a higher up. A lot of the politics get in the way because of this. Frequently, more important work will be sidelined because someone needs something and they are friends with a VP. Because this is so effective, name dropping is used a lot to expedite less important work.

Management lacks a lot of transparency and will, a lot of time, lie to employees just to keep them satisfied in the short term. Questions about certain things will be avoided or ignored. False promises are made to keep morale high. Promises of raises and promotions will be made with no follow through. Worse is, sometimes, they will give an unofficial promotion and not follow through with the official one. Because of this, you will be expected to do higher tier work at a lower tier pay. They will do anything to milk as much as they can from employees without actually compensating them for it.

Communication is atrocious. Policies will be put in place with no official communication about the policy. Employees are expected to follow these new policies despite having never heard of them. Structural changes in management are frequent and rarely relayed to the employees officially. It is very common for someone to have been your boss for over a month and you not know about it unless you keep up with the rumor mill.

Lack of prioritization. I touched on this earlier when talking about nepotism. Essentially, work that is actually important and work that you are told is important can be very different. Frequently, there is a constant struggle of what work should be done first. This task isn't a difficult task, but Liberty likes complicate things. Work will need to be pushed off because a VP needs something that could probably wait right now. Even your direct chain of supervisors will have a conflict on what work should be prioritized. This frequently leading to situations where your direct manager wants X done, your Director wants Y done, but the CIO has eyes on project Z. No matter which you prioritize you will be reprimanded.

Having your name on certain projects can have you put on a naughty list. No matter what role you play in a project, if that project goes south, you will be blamed for it.

Pay is well below industry standard. Liberty uses the Mission Statement as a way to take advantage of people who actually believe they are changing lives. Many of my former colleges are brilliant and talented individuals that would double their salary by leaving the company but fall trap in the belief of the Mission Statement.

Workload can sometimes be too much. I don't want to bash them too much for this as it is something they genuinely try to avoid. It is really a symptom of lack of experienced help. Due to Liberty's subpar pay, experienced employees leave en masse (a lot of the times to the same company). They are unable to hire any decent help externally as experienced engineers don't want the low ball offers. They end up moving people up internally. This isn't necessarily a bad thing as it does offer room for career improvement. The problem is that people leave so frequently that they end up having inexperienced Juniors in Senior level positions.

Being set up for failure happens a lot. Due to the turnaround of engineers, you will be put into positions way outside of your comfort zone. You will be expected to succeed when the odds are heavily stacked against you.

pros: I work within the IT organization, and the caliber of people that work in IT are for the most part incredible. We get to work with some high-end technology, and are far ahead of institutions like UVA, VT, etc. Coworkers with in-demand technical skill sets have left and gone to Facebook, Apple, Dropbox, etc. If you do well and are in the right position, you can advance. If you're an entry level HelpDesk staff member and are competent, you can advance quickly into a real Sysadmin role and eventually leave for a better opportunity. My team is great, and there is no expectation to work overtime/long hours.
cons:
Internal politics are ridiculous at times. It's a game of who's ego in the VP suite is going to get bruised if something is suggested that they don't like (looking at you, Marketing!). At times the volume of work can be heavy, and the internal IT bureaucracy can feel stifling - lots of red tape that you will need to learn to navigate.  

An extraordinary amount of money is wasted on ridiculous requests for VPs and "special" departments. The parking is atrocious, but getting somewhat better. The statements that the president of the university makes about the election, local/national politics, etc are embarrassing both as alumni and as a staff member, and I'm worried that they are going to hurt me in future career endeavors. 

Of course - elephant in the room is pay. Honestly, it's shameful, especially in light of how much money the President makes and how much he is spending. If it weren't for the education benefits, I would get much more serious about looking for a new job. When a neighbor found out I worked for Liberty, their response was "how do you afford your mortgage?!" Of course, when he says things like "Donald Trump reminds me of my father" what else would you expect.

pros:
It is a real blessing to have the freedom to speak to students on the phone about Christ. I have been able to pray with many students who are enduring challenging circumstances in their life.

Education benefits are decent. 

Great coworkers!
cons:
The pay is not competitive when compared to the national average. This leads to a low retention rate across departments which leads to a lot of problems.

The employee receives 18 credit hours to use each academic year. Their dependents can go to school full time. This is not helpful for employees who are pursuing their Undergraduate degrees. It would take over 6 years for the employee to finish their Bachelor's degree. UG students should receive a higher amount of credit hours per year.

There is no paid paternal leave. If you or your spouse is pregnant, then you better save all of your vacation and sick days if you want to bring home a paycheck or two. This is disheartening since LU prides itself on their values. If LU was truly a pro-life and pro-family institution, then they should provide at least 2 weeks of paid paternal leave to their employees. 

Your shift is (supposedly) dependent upon seniority. The problem is you cannot move up to a better shift unless a better slot opens up. Better slots that are snatched up by new employees. The purpose is to provide each Advisor a different time of day to reach out to their students. The problem is it gives no stability of life to the employee. You could come to work at a different time every single day, or you can just work a consistent (yet terrible) schedule. 

Moving off the phones and receiving a promotion is ambiguous. Instead of posting opportunities for advancement to employees with appropriate work experience (1 year or more due to the high amount of turnover), promotions are given behind closed doors and announced via e-mail. You simply hope to be chosen by management to be part of those discussions.

review_title: Liberty University has no Proctored Online Tests, what a JOKE
pros:

My colleagues are genuinely sincere Christians. I only wish this school was genuinely Christian in the way it treats its employees. We sell the lack of tenure here as a method to route out heresy, but in fact it is license to fire whoever administration feels like whenever it conveniences them. Faculty of many departments are let go after decade(s) of service because online course offering forces shrinking of residential courses. There is NO FACULTY oversight of this "university". You are micromanaged in every aspect of your existence here and it gets worse with each passing year. No one complains openly because we're all afraid of getting fired. At my church, talking with my Sunday School teacher, I learned my experience is in fact pretty much universal. 

At a usual school, it is sad to see too much taught by adjuncts because we know they are largely underpaid and undervalued. Here it is so much worse. The online adjunct for Liberty University Online is actually not even free to make their own course materials. For one, they are not paid enough to make it worth their time. But, worse yet, all modifications of the online course are made through the SME (subject matter expert). This adjunct or prof is the sole course coordinator. This pays less than $1000 per semester, or if the SME is not teaching, literally nothing. This SME is pretty much the only defense we have against the online course being wholesale copied by various cheat sites. Our defense is paper thin at best. Personally, I have come to believe this is by design because administration knows most of our online students are cheating. Money not excellence is their guide. More on this later.

One of our 5 Vice Provosts was fired in the middle of a semester with no explanation to the faculty except a vague email to "not contact her, she was ok..." . See what you find about that. Probably nothing, because this place has a stranglehold on local media.  What other university would tolerate a beloved Vice Provost being terminated with seemingly no cause mid-semester? I cannot state the name here due to community guidelines and this person has not spoken up since I'm guessing a non-disclosure agreement is at play. Many of her subordinates quit after this since she was one of the only sane voices at her administrative level. 

Many good faculty are leaving her to work at Longwood University which is only about an hour from here. Many others who have been let go work at the CC across the street. Still others cannot find jobs because they were let go after more than a decade of service for essentially no cause.

Of course, finding controversy here is hard since it seems the University President has a team of editors devoted to scrubbing away truth about Liberty on the Wikipedia page. 

I am truly sorry that so many parents send their children here because they buy the hype. If you are looking for a school where faculty really are able to mentor your kids one-on-one then look elsewhere. The faculty/student ratio here is sad, and don't be fooled by the conflation of online adjuncts with actual faculty. Do you want your kid's course to be some internet prof's part time job ?

This is not a selective school. If you have money they will take it. 

Liberty University Online is a home for outright cheating. It is well-known among those who teach online that there is a significant portion of the students using cheat sites to take their classes. The faculty have requested that online courses have tests which are proctored. In fact,the Philosophy Department showed that residential students were cheating the online intro to Philosophy course about a decade ago by simply forcing them to take the test in a monitored room. The grade distributions were markedly lower when the students were proctored.

What did the university do when wide-scale cheating was shown likely by a department ? NOTHING. In fact, I have seen administration punish faculty and departments who stand up for academic excellence. Not only are they not interested in catching cheaters and protecting the reputation of our degrees, they are invested in covering up and making it hard to see the breadth and depth of the cheating happening here. In the past decade we have radically weakened punishments for cheating. The online adminstrative leader was instrumental of rail-roading new cheating policies through the Faculty Senate which now essentially make cheating a total joke. It used to be we could assign an F for the course if we found they had used a cheat site to do a test (keep in mind, ALL online tests for LUO are OPEN BOOK & OPEN INTERNET, so the value of an LUO degree is pretty much open to debate!). Now, we just get a 30% deduction on an assignment.

Also notable, we had a grade of Fd for Failed with Dishonestly. That was removed because it is easier to paper over cheating with a simple "F".

Seriously Christian parents, send your kids somewhere else. This place is not worth your money or your child's time. It pains me to write this but, someone needs to start stating this plainly.  

 Consider this, we have residential students who take tests in classrooms with actual supervision of professors. Yet, online, we are forbidden from instituting proctoring in the courses. It is plainly fraudulent.

Now, students are at times at the hands of extortionists because they hire someone to take the course for them and then the criminal they hired turns and extorts them for money. If LUO allowed the faculty freedom to put proctoring in their courses then this criminal mischief would be largely ended.

LUO has a profit margin of 80% or so and yet we refuse to pay our online adjuncts any reasonable portion. In addition, the school works hard to redefine roles to keep workers from working "full-time" jobs. This sort of gamesmanship with federal regulation is just the routine here. You're never safe here because your worth as an individual created by God is meaningless to administration. No, we don't care about people, we care about profits. Administration may say otherwise, but their actions speak to a wholesale disdain for the work of faculty.

Promotions were based solely on call scores and not at all on leadership ability. If you get tired of being treated like crap and want to move to a different department within Liberty, you have to get permission from your boss' boss' boss to apply for these positions. This has become a major issue across multiple departments. Because these supervisors are unused to conflict, they have a lot of trouble training/correcting/confronting agents. Of the dozens of meetings I had one on one with my direct supervisor, there was only one in which they were able to address an issue in my calls. Once I suggested that it could help the team if the supervisor made our individual meetings shorter so they had time to listen to more calls (and be more familiar with each agents ability) and pull people off the floor for less time. Huge mistake! The supervisor got offended and said that they didn't have enough time to listen to more calls because they were too busy. Everyone in our 12 person team had the same experience in those meetings, 50 minutes of talking about nothing, 10 minutes of talking about work. 
HR is next to unavailable, especially since they are on a separate campus and only send over a representative once a year. 
There is a double standard when it comes to compensation and expectation. Employees are expected to make work their priority, but are treated without respect. 
Maternity leave is short. No paternity leave. 
You have to pay for your parking pass, it is taken out of your paychecks. Even though they own the parking lots, you still need to pay for the pass.
Education benefit is not worth it. You get 18 credit hours a school year (F/S/Summer) and their programs change frequently so you may end up working for your degree for extra years. The majority of the classes online are formatted so that the "professor" has as little work to do as possible. It would be worth it to find another job, save up the money, and then take off 2 years to attend a program in person. 

Company culture? Treat people like high school students at a private christian school. Strictly enforce the parts of a conservative working environment that have little correlation to productivity and focus on making the school more money, even if it screws over the employees and the students.

My advice to a potential employee? Don't get sucked in. People who work here call it a black hole,  is that really what you want?

Where do I start?

Morale among many employees is uncommonly low. A couple years ago, senior management launched an employee satisfaction initiative they entitled, "You Matter." Basically, they wanted to boost morale amongst employees so they created an internal PR campaign designed to make us feel like what we do is important. It's pretty standard for any business to do such things. However, part of the launch of the "You Matter" campaign was a meeting wherein every employee was required to attend. 

At said meeting, senior management promised to hire an outside economic firm to compare every employee's salary to the national average for that particular field. They promised that they would release the study in August of 2012 and that everyone would likely get a raise. Employees were extremely excited about that prospect, since it's pretty well known that Liberty does not pay well.  Rather, they don't pay rank-and-file employees well. All senior management have salary and benefits packages in the six-figures according to the IRS. It has been almost 2 years and employees have yet to hear about that raise. Some people familiar with upper management say they are just hoping employees forget about that promise.
 
"You Matter?" To many of us, that phrase has become a sarcastic punch line at the end of in-office jokes. Upper management talks about how much the employees matter, but there is a UNCOMMONLY HIGH turnover rate. This doesn't really concern the management though, because each year the residential side of the university cranks out 3,000 more fresh graduates, many of whom stay in Lynchburg and need jobs. In other words, the high turnover rate is counterbalanced by the constant stream of new hires. 

The fact is that LU sees no need to make things better for employees. They don't mind a massive turnover rate, because it means lower salaries for longer.
